subject: history
title: Revolt of 1857: Key Leaders & Regional Centers
description: Comprehensive table of leaders, their regions, contributions, and fates

rows.name: Bahadur Shah Zafar II
rows.title: Last Mughal Emperor (1837-1857)
rows.contribution: Symbolic head of revolt; provided legitimacy

details.description: 82-year-old reluctant leader who became symbol of Indian unity
points: Declared Emperor of India on 11 May 1857
Tried by British after fall of Delhi
Famous poet (Urdu, Persian); wrote poems in exile
Death marked end of Mughal dynasty
details.impact: His symbolic presence united diverse rebel groups under one banner

rows.name: Rani Lakshmibai
rows.title: Queen of Jhansi; widow of Maharaja Gangadhar Rao
rows.contribution: Led defense of Jhansi; guerrilla warfare

details.description: Most iconic woman warrior of the revolt, aged 29 at death
points: Husband died 1853; British denied adoption rights
Escaped with adopted son on horseback
Fought dressed as man in Battle of Kotah-ki-Serai
details.impact: Became symbol of resistance; inspired future freedom fighters

rows.name: Nana Sahib (Dhondu Pant)
rows.title: Adopted son of Peshwa Baji Rao II

details.description: Maratha leader who sought restoration of Peshwa position
points: British stopped his pension after Baji Rao II's death
Personal grievance against Doctrine of Lapse
Led successful siege of British entrenchment
Controversially associated with Satichaura Ghat massacre
British blamed him for Bibighar massacre (likely done by subordinates)
Escaped after British recapture; went to Nepal
British never confirmed his capture or death
Some reports claim he died in Nepal jungle

details.description: Most capable military commander of the revolt
points: Conducted guerrilla warfare for a year after main revolt
Maintained resistance longer than any other leader
details.impact: Demonstrated Indian capability in military leadership

rows.name: Begum Hazrat Mahal
rows.title: Wife of Nawab Wajid Ali Shah
rows.contribution: Led Awadh rebellion after husband's exile

details.description: Powerful woman leader who ruled Awadh during revolt
points: Also known as Begum of Awadh
Took charge after husband exiled to Calcutta
Proclaimed her son Birjis Qadr as Nawab
Escaped to Nepal after fall of Lucknow
British offered pardon but she refused
details.impact: Showed women's leadership in political and military spheres

rows.name: Kunwar Singh
rows.title: Raja of Jagdishpur; Zamindar
rows.contribution: Led revolt in Bihar; fought at age 80

details.description: Octogenarian warrior who achieved remarkable victories
points: Born 1777; was 80 years old during revolt
Affected by oppressive land revenue policies
Led successful campaign in Bihar and UP
Defeated British at Battle of Arrah (1857)
Arm injured in battle; amputated own arm
Won battle at Jagdishpur just before death
One of few who died fighting till the end
details.impact: Proved age no barrier to resistance; inspired Bihar region

details.description: Attempted to establish alternative government in Rohilkhand
details.impact: Showed rebels' attempt at governance, not just military resistance

details.description: Powerful religious leader who gave revolt a jihad character
points: British saw him as dangerous agitator
Killed by British-backed Raja of Powayan

rows.name: Mangal Pandey
rows.title: Sepoy, 34th Bengal Native Infantry
rows.contribution: First to openly rebel; attacked officers

details.description: Soldier whose act of defiance sparked the revolt
points: Born in Nagwa, UP; Brahmin caste
Attacked Sergeant-Major and Adjutant on 29 March
Called fellow sepoys to join revolt
Tried to shoot himself but survived
British used 'Pandy' as derogatory term for rebels
details.impact: His martyrdom inspired sepoys across India; symbol of resistance

rows.name: Bakht Khan
rows.title: Subedar, Bareilly Brigade
rows.contribution: Commander-in-Chief of rebel forces at Delhi

details.description: Experienced military commander who led Delhi defense
points: Appointed Commander of rebel forces by Bahadur Shah
Organized defense of Delhi during siege
details.impact: Provided military expertise to untrained rebel forces

details.description: Leader who organized peasant resistance in Haryana
points: Organized revolt in Rewari, Gurgaon, Rohtak
details.impact: Extended revolt to areas near British capital

rows.name: Birjis Qadr
rows.title: Son of Wajid Ali Shah; proclaimed Nawab

details.description: Young prince who became nominal ruler during revolt
points: Mother Begum Hazrat Mahal ruled as regent
details.impact: Represented continuity of Awadh royal house

data.summary: The revolt saw diverse leadership from royalty, military commanders, and religious figures. Women like Rani Lakshmibai and Begum Hazrat Mahal played crucial roles. Most leaders either died fighting, were executed, or died in exile. Their sacrifice inspired future freedom movements.
